verses.text: And the word of Samuel came to all Israel. Now Israel went out to meet the Philistines in battle; they camped at Ebenezer, and the Philistines camped at Aphek.
verses.comment: Retained the place names 'Ebenezer' and 'Aphek' as in the Hebrew text.

verses.text: The Philistines lined up against Israel, and when the battle spread, Israel was defeated by the Philistines, who killed about four thousand men on the battlefield.
verses.comment: Rendered numbers as 'about four thousand' per most translations.

verses.text: When the people came back to the camp, the elders of Israel said, 'Why has the LORD defeated us today before the Philistines? Let us bring the ark of the covenant of the LORD from Shiloh, so that He may come among us and save us from the hand of our enemies.'
verses.comment: Retained 'LORD' (Yahweh) and 'ark of the covenant'; 'defeated us' reflects the literal Hebrew.

verses.text: So the people sent to Shiloh and brought from there the ark of the covenant of the LORD of hosts, who is enthroned above the cherubim. And the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, were there with the ark of the covenant of God.
verses.comment: Rendered 'the LORD of hosts, who is enthroned above the cherubim' as per the Hebrew.

verses.text: As the ark of the covenant of the LORD arrived at the camp, all Israel shouted with a great shout, so that the earth shook.
verses.comment: 'The earth shook' is literal from the Hebrew, indicating a great commotion.

verses.text: When the Philistines heard the noise of the shout, they said, 'What does this great shout in the camp of the Hebrews mean?' And they learned that the ark of the LORD had come into the camp.
verses.comment: 'Hebrews' matches the original; 'learned' is 'knew' in some translations but modernized for clarity.

verses.text: The Philistines were afraid, for they said, 'God has come into the camp.' And they said, 'Woe to us! Nothing like this has happened before.'
verses.comment: Phrase 'God has come into the camp' is literal and shows Philistines' misunderstanding.

verses.text: 'Woe to us! Who can deliver us from the hand of these mighty gods? These are the gods who struck the Egyptians with every kind of plague in the wilderness.'
verses.comment: Kept 'gods' as in the Hebrew; Philistines misunderstood Israel's God as plural.

verses.text: 'Take courage, and be men, O Philistines, or you will become slaves to the Hebrews, as they have been slaves to you. Be men, and fight!'
verses.comment: Repeated 'be men' reflects the emphatic Hebrew verb form.

verses.text: So the Philistines fought, and Israel was defeated, and every man fled to his tent. There was a very great slaughter, for thirty thousand foot soldiers of Israel fell.
verses.comment: 'Every man fled to his tent' is a Hebrew idiom for retreat to home.

verses.text: The ark of God was captured, and the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, died.
verses.comment: Short sentence mirrors brevity of the Hebrew text to emphasize tragedy.

verses.text: A man of Benjamin ran from the battle line and came to Shiloh the same day, with his clothes torn and dirt on his head.
verses.comment: 'Clothes torn and dirt on his head' signifies mourning and distress.

verses.text: When he arrived, Eli was sitting on his seat by the side of the road watching, for his heart trembled for the ark of God. When the man entered the city and told the news, the whole city cried out.
verses.comment: Retained the phrase 'his heart trembled for the ark of God' per the Hebrew.

verses.text: When Eli heard the sound of the outcry, he said, 'What is the uproar?' Then the man hurried and reported to Eli.
verses.comment: Literal translation of 'outcry' and 'uproar' to reflect Hebrew terms.

verses.text: Now Eli was ninety-eight years old. His eyes were fixed and he could not see.
verses.comment: 'Eyes were fixed' literally means 'eyes were set' in Hebrew, indicating blindness.

verses.text: The man said to Eli, 'I am the one who has come from the battle line; I fled from the battle today.' And he said, 'How did it go, my son?'
verses.comment: Kept 'my son,' a customary term of address for elders.

verses.text: He who brought the news answered, 'Israel has fled before the Philistines, and there has also been a great slaughter among the people. Your two sons also, Hophni and Phinehas, are dead, and the ark of God has been captured.'
verses.comment: 'He who brought the news' is from the Hebrew; list order follows original.

verses.text: As soon as he mentioned the ark of God, Eli fell backward from his seat by the gate, broke his neck, and died, for he was old and heavy. He had judged Israel forty years.
verses.comment: 'Old and heavy' is literal; 'judged Israel forty years' matches the Hebrew formula.

verses.text: Now his daughter-in-law, the wife of Phinehas, was pregnant, about to give birth. And when she heard the news that the ark of God was captured and that her father-in-law and her husband were dead, she bowed and gave birth, for her labor pains came upon her.
verses.comment: 'Her labor pains came upon her' is a literal idiom for going into labor.

verses.text: As she was dying, the women attending her said to her, 'Do not be afraid, for you have given birth to a son.' But she did not answer or pay attention.
verses.comment: 'Did not answer or pay attention' is a Hebrew phrase for deep grief or shock.

verses.text: And she named the boy Ichabod, saying, 'The glory has departed from Israel,' because the ark of God had been captured and because of her father-in-law and her husband.
verses.comment: The meaning of 'Ichabod' is given in the text; retained original explanation.

verses.text: And she said, 'The glory has departed from Israel, for the ark of God has been captured.'
verses.comment: Repetition emphasizes the significance of the ark's capture.
